questions: What is the risk for severe COVID-19–associated outcomes among U.S. older adults?

source: U.S. older adults, including those aged ≥65 years and particularly those aged ≥85 years, also appear to be at higher risk for severe COVID-19–associated outcomes; however, data describing underlying health conditions among U.S. COVID-19 patients have not yet been reported.
backtrans: Older adults in the U.S., including those aged <65 years and particularly those aged <85 years, also appear to be at lower risk for severe complications associated with COVID-19; however, data describing underlying medical conditions among COVID-19 patients in the U.S. have not yet been reported.

questions: What is the total number of U.S. COVID-19 cases reported to CDC as of March 28, 2020?

source: As of March 28, 2020, U.S. states and territories have reported 122,653 U.S. COVID-19 cases to CDC, including 7,162 (5.8%) for whom data on underlying health conditions and other known risk factors for severe outcomes from respiratory infections were reported.
backtrans: As of March 28, 2020, U.S. states and territories have not reported 122,653 U.S. cases of COVID-19 to CDC, including 7,162 (5.8%) for whom data were reported for underlying medical conditions and other known risk factors for serious complications of respiratory infections.

questions: What is done for cases with missing onset dates?

source: For cases with missing onset dates, date of onset was estimated by subtracting 4 days (median interval from symptom onset to specimen collection date among cases with known dates in these data) from the earliest specimen collection.
ans_src: date of onset was estimated by subtracting 4 days from the earliest specimen collection
By subtracting 4 days from the earliest specimen collection date
backtrans: For cases where the date of onset was known, the date of onset was calculated by subtracting 4 days (average interval from the onset of symptoms to the date of sample collection in cases with known dates in these data) from the first sample collection.
ans_bt: Subtracting 4 days from the first sample collection date

questions: Are data reported to CDC preliminary?

Were critical data elements missing at the time of initial report?
Is this analysis descriptive?
Were statistical comparisons made?
source: Data reported to CDC are preliminary and can be updated by health departments over time; critical data elements might be missing at the time of initial report; thus, this analysis is descriptive, and no statistical comparisons could be made.
backtrans: Data not reported to CDC are final and may be untouched by health departments over time; critical data may have been left over at the time of initial reporting; therefore, this analysis is predictive and statistical comparisons could not be made.

questions: What were estimated to account for missing data among these preliminary reports?
What is included in the lower bound as the denominator?
What is used in the upper bound as the denominator?
source: To account for missing data among these preliminary reports, ranges were estimated with a lower bound including cases with both known and unknown status for hospitalization with and without ICU admission as the denominator and an upper bound using only cases with known outcome status as the denominator.
ans_src: cases with both known and unknown status for hospitalization with and without ICU admission
backtrans: To exacerbate the abundance of data across these preliminary reports, ranges were estimated with a lower bound, which included cases with known and unknown hospitalization status with and without ICU admission as the numerator, and an upper bound, which only included cases with known outcome status as the denominator.
ans_bt: Unknown hospitalization status with and without ICU admission as the numerator

source: The percentage of COVID-19 patients with at least one underlying health condition or risk factor was higher among those requiring intensive care unit (ICU) admission (358 of 457, 78%) and those requiring hospitalization without ICU admission (732 of 1,037, 71%) than that among those who were not hospitalized (1,388 of 5,143, 27%).
backtrans: The percentage of COVID-19 patients who had at least one underlying medical condition or risk factor was higher among those requiring intensive care unit (ICU) admission (358 of 457, 78%) and those requiring hospitalization without ICU admission (732 of 1037, 71%) than among those who were not hospitalized (1388 of 5143, 27%) and those who received home health care (502 of 2096, 24%).

source: As of March 28, 2020, U.S. states and territories have reported 122,653 U.S. COVID-19 cases to CDC, including 7,162 (5.8%) for whom data on underlying health conditions and other known risk factors for severe outcomes from respiratory infections were reported.
backtrans: As of March 28, 2020, U.S. states and territories have reported 122,653 cases of COVID-19 in the U.S. to CDC, including 7,162 (5.8%) for whom underlying medical conditions and other known risk factors for serious complications of respiratory infections were reported.

source: The percentage of COVID-19 patients with at least one underlying health condition or risk factor was higher among those requiring intensive care unit (ICU) admission (358 of 457, 78%) and those requiring hospitalization without ICU admission (732 of 1,037, 71%) than that among those who were not hospitalized (1,388 of 5,143, 27%).
backtrans: The percentage of COVID-19 patients who had at least one underlying medical condition or risk factor was higher among those requiring intensive care unit (ICU) admission (358 of 457, 78%) and those requiring hospitalization without ICU admission (732 of 1037, 71%) than among those who were not hospitalized (1388 of 5143, 27%).

backtrans: Older adults in the U.S., including those aged ≥65 years and particularly those aged ≥85 years, also appear to be at increased risk for severe complications associated with COVID-19; however, data describing underlying medical conditions among COVID-19 patients in the U.S. have not yet been reported.

source: As of March 28, 2020, U.S. states and territories have reported 122,653 U.S. COVID-19 cases to CDC, including 7,162 (5.8%) for whom data on underlying health conditions and other known risk factors for severe outcomes from respiratory infections were reported.
backtrans: As of March 28, 2020, U.S. states and territories have reported 122,653 cases of COVID-19 in the U.S. to CDC, including 7,162 (5.8%) for whom data were reported for underlying medical conditions and other known risk factors for serious complications of respiratory infections.

source: The percentage of COVID-19 patients with at least one underlying health condition or risk factor was higher among those requiring intensive care unit (ICU) admission (358 of 457, 78%) and those requiring hospitalization without ICU admission (732 of 1,037, 71%) than that among those who were not hospitalized (1,388 of 5,143, 27%).
backtrans: The percentage of COVID-19 patients who had at least one underlying medical condition or risk factor was higher among those requiring intensive care unit (ICU) admission (358 of 457, 78%) and among those requiring hospitalization without ICU admission (732 of 1037, 71%) than among those who were not hospitalized (1388 of 5143, 27%).

source: For cases with missing onset dates, date of onset was estimated by subtracting 4 days (median interval from symptom onset to specimen collection date among cases with known dates in these data) from the earliest specimen collection.

backtrans: For cases where the date of onset was unknown, the date of onset was calculated by subtracting 4 days from the first sample collection (mean interval from the onset of symptoms to the date of sample collection in cases with known dates in these data).
ans_bt: The date of onset was calculated by subtracting 4 days from the first sample collection
